artist: Peter Strüb the Younger (Master of Messkirch)
creditline: The Bergmann Richards Memorial Fund and the Fiduciary Fund
provenance: The Princes of Liechtenstein, Schloss Seebenstein, Vienna, Austria. (Gallery P. de Boer, Amsterdam, The Netherlands by 1964). H. Becker, Dortmund. The Netherlands. (Gallery Hans Cramer, The Hague, The Netherlands by 1975 through 1982); purchased by MIA in 1982.
text: Mary of Egypt had been a prostitute, known widely for her strong sexual desires before she suddenly repented and became a hermit in the desert. Much like Mary Magdalen, after resisting all worldly temptations she was able to ascend to heaven which might account for the confusion of their stories. Here, the long, disheveled hair covering Mary of Egypt’s body represents her rejection of feminine sensuality despite her former beauty.
title: The Elevation of the Magdalene or of St. Mary of Egypt
